text:
Q: Report number of assertions in pyTest A:

Quick n' dirty rough estimate for files starting with test_:

grep -r "assert" test_* | wc -l

Caveats: This counts the number of assert statements in python source code, so an assert in a loop only counts as one statement. And if you have a variable/function/string containing "assert", it'll count those too (but shouldn't be a problem for most code)

For an exact count, Display number of assertions in python unit tests

Q: What is the parentheses doing to my code? A:

Your code may not run on windows.

Please replace this line

subprocess.run("arecord", "-d", str(5)), "-f", "cd", filename)

With

subprocess.run(["arecord", "-d", str(duration), "-f", "cd", filename])

Q: What errors other return code indicate? return 1? return 100? is there a standard? A:

C++ has an ISO standard that defines the language, including what a main function is.

cppreference.com is a common reference that mostly comes from the standard documents, but a little bit more friendly to read, search and compare between different standard versions.

You can consult cppreference.com page for "main function" to see what is required for a main function, including its return type and the meaning of its return value. What you mentioned by "the compiler will generate return 0; for you" is also explicitly stated in the standard, not merely a compiler's decision.

Note that with respect to the return value of main, the standard says

Execution of the return (or the implicit return upon reaching the end of main) is equivalent to first leaving the function normally (which destroys the objects with automatic storage duration and evaluates any postcondition assertions of main) and then calling std::exit with the same argument as the argument of the return (std::exit then destroys static objects and terminates the program).

Go to std::exit:

Control is returned to the host environment. If exit_code is 0 or EXIT_SUCCESS, an implementation-defined status indicating successful termination is returned. If exit_code is EXIT_FAILURE, an implementation-defined status indicating unsuccessful termination is returned. In other cases implementation-defined status value is returned.

Actually, the programmer has much freedom to decide what value to return. For example, the grep command's manual says that

Normally the exit status is 0 if a line is selected, 1 if no lines were selected, and 2 if an error occurred.

Q: How to draw a curved border in Flutter A:

try this way

 Container(
  width: 500,
  height: 200,
  decoration: BoxDecoration(
    border: const Border(
      top: BorderSide(
        color: Color.fromRGBO(227, 235, 254, 1),
        width: 5.0,
      ),

    ),
          color:Color.fromRGBO(227, 235, 254, 1),
    
    boxShadow: [
      BoxShadow(
        color: Colors.black.withValues(alpha: 0.1),
        blurRadius: 8.0,
        offset: const Offset(0, 4),
      ),
    ],
   
  ),
  child:  Column(
    
    children: [
      Container(height:195,width:500,
                decoration:BoxDecoration(borderRadius: const BorderRadius.only(
      topLeft: Radius.circular(12),
      topRight: Radius.circular(12),
    ),      color:Colors.white,),
      child:
                
               Center(child: Text(
      'Your Content Here',
      style: TextStyle(fontSize: 16, fontWeight: FontWeight.w500),
    ),))]
  ),
)

Q: How do you change the launcher logo of an app in Android Studio? A:

go to AndroidManifest.xml and change the android:icon="@mipmap/ic_launcher" to android:icon="@mipmap/(your image name)" suppose you have a image named telugu and you want it to be set as your app icon then change android:icon="@mipmap/telugu" and you have to copy and paste your image into mipmap folder
